citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
In the letter to the Institutional Official (IO) regarding the semiannual report of the animal care and use program review
and facilities inspection dated 7 August 2023, IACUC approval of the letter had not been given prior to delivery of the
document. The Institutional animal care and use committee (IACUC) must prepare reports of its evaluations and submit
the reports to the IO of the research facility. The reports shall be reviewed and signed by a majority of the IACUC
members and submitted upon completion of the program review and inspection.
Correct by 11/29/2023

citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The facility has an umbrella protocol for the evaluation of the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic evaluation of test
materials. Each test material studied has its own separate detailed study protocol followed under the umbrella. It was
noted by Inspectors that the study director/principal investigator for the umbrella protocol was different than the study
director/principal investigator for the test material protocol. The AWA and regulations define the principal investigator as a
single individual responsible for the proposal to conduct research and for the design and implementation of research
involving animals. With separate study directors, it is not possible to know who is responsible for the design and
implementation of the research. Proposed activities and proposed significant changes in ongoing activities that have been
approved by the IACUC may be subject to further appropriate review and approval by officials of the research facility.
However, those officials may not approve an activity involving the care and use of animals if it has not been approved by
the IACUC.
Correct by 12/11/2023

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.
citations.narrative:
Several facility documents were noted during inspection that limit the Attending Veterinarian’s authority to treat animals in
their care. The facility’s “Standard Operating Procedure for the Documentation and Response for Laboratory Animal
Health Reports and Treatment Plans” describes actions veterinary staff should follow prior to administering treatment,
including to “obtain permission from the SD (study director) and the Veterinarian before administering treatment. This
requirement may only be waived for time-critical emergencies and only if the SD is not immediately available. The SD
must approve or deny any treatments before implementation.” In addition, one of the facility’s study protocols states that
“euthanasia of moribund animals will be authorized by the Study Director or Veterinarian with the concurrence of the
Study Director.” The last document is an animal health report form which includes a “Review and Approval of
Assessment/Plan” portion on the bottom of the form. This section allows the SD to approve or decline the proposed
treatment plan, including the time the approval was obtained. An example of this occurred on 9/4/23, where the
veterinarian recommended euthanasia due to the declining clinical condition of the animal and waited for SD approval to
euthanize. If the attending Veterinarian cannot make decisions about veterinary care without consent from study directors,
this could lead to unnecessary pain and suffering of the animals. Each research facility shall assure that the Attending
Veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the provision of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of
other aspects of animal care and use.
Correct by 12/4/2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
KATHARINE FRANK, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.31(c)(3) 
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). 
In the letter to the Institutional Official (IO) regarding the semiannual report of the animal care and use program review 
and facilities inspection dated 7 August 2023, IACUC approval of the letter had not been given prior to delivery of the 
document. The Institutional animal care and use committee (IACUC) must prepare reports of its evaluations and submit 
the reports to the IO of the research facility. The reports shall be reviewed and signed by a majority of the IACUC 
members and submitted upon completion of the program review and inspection. 
 
Correct by 11/29/2023 
2.31(d)(8) 
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). 
The facility has an umbrella protocol for the evaluation of the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic evaluation of test 
materials. Each test material studied has its own separate detailed study protocol followed under the umbrella. It was 
noted by Inspectors that the study director/principal investigator for the umbrella protocol was different than the study 
director/principal investigator for the test material protocol. The AWA and regulations define the principal investigator as a 
single individual responsible for the proposal to conduct research and for the design and implementation of research 
involving animals. With separate study directors, it is not possible to know who is responsible for the design and 
implementation of the research. Proposed activities and proposed significant changes in ongoing activities that have been 
approved by the IACUC may be subject to further appropriate review and approval by officials of the research facility. 
However, those officials may not approve an activity involving the care and use of animals if it has not been approved by 
the IACUC. 
 
Correct by 12/11/2023 
2.33(a)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care. 
Several facility documents were noted during inspection that limit the Attending Veterinarian’s authority to treat animals in 
their care. The facility’s “Standard Operating Procedure for the Documentation and Response for Laboratory Animal

Health Reports and Treatment Plans” describes actions veterinary staff should follow prior to administering treatment, 
including to “obtain permission from the SD (study director) and the Veterinarian before administering treatment. This 
requirement may only be waived for time-critical emergencies and only if the SD is not immediately available. The SD 
must approve or deny any treatments before implementation.” In addition, one of the facility’s study protocols states that 
“euthanasia of moribund animals will be authorized by the Study Director or Veterinarian with the concurrence of the 
Study Director.” The last document is an animal health report form which includes a “Review and Approval of 
Assessment/Plan” portion on the bottom of the form. This section allows the SD to approve or decline the proposed 
treatment plan, including the time the approval was obtained. An example of this occurred on 9/4/23, where the 
veterinarian recommended euthanasia due to the declining clinical condition of the animal and waited for SD approval to 
euthanize. If the attending Veterinarian cannot make decisions about veterinary care without consent from study directors, 
this could lead to unnecessary pain and suffering of the animals. Each research facility shall assure that the Attending 
Veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the provision of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of 
other aspects of animal care and use.  
 
Correct by 12/4/2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KATHARINE FRANK, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
